posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Devastating Critical: A Commentary
Stagmeister wrote:[Devastating Critical], it's the pinnacle of a strength-based build. But it's all about balance. Dexterous types have Epic Dodge as their summit, those squishy mages and their ilk (and yes, I'm including those supposedly holy types here) get an assortment of insta-death spells, this is just us grunts saying, "see how you like it, sunshine."

And even where it's not forbidden or nerfed, folk can defend against it. A good fortitude save is a start, but those casters have some nasty defences they can throw up, and it won't work as a first (ie most likely to hit) attack on a build with ED - and that's leaving aside crit-immune types. The list goes on...

Spell-chuckers: whingers, the lot of 'em.

And that's the essence of my argument, Shia. I keep meaning to bring the whole thing about Dev Crit up on a thread in the General Discussion forum, but other things always seem to get in the way. Life, eh?
NWN Wiki wrote:
  • This feat is often banned from online persistent world multiplayer servers as some consider it overpowered.
Devastating critical is considered the pinnacle of a strength-based build, on par with Epic Dodge for dexterity types, Dragon Shape for Druids & Shifters, and Epic Mage Armor / Epic Warding for Mages.

There are some downsides to devastating critical however. Here is a brief discussion and some tips. 

Some of this is simply my opinion and can be subject to further debate in the thread.

Pre-requisites

Strength 25+
Power Attack
Cleave
Great Cleave
Improved Critical [both melee and ranged weapons]
Overwhelming Critical

A level of monk will save only one feat (cleave) as power attack is required to be taken to obtain great cleave.

Recommended

Base AB 40+ (at level 40)
Weapon with 18-20 or 19-20 threat range 
- 15-20 / 17-20 with improved critical, 12-20 / 15-20 with keen

Base Strength 28+ (for base Str 40 when capped) -> Fort save 39-45 or die at level 40

Likely base fortitude saves of opponents at level 40

High save: 22 + cons modifier + save feats
Low save 12 + cons modifier + save feats

(pre-epic multiclassing ie Fighter/Cleric can modify this slightly, also module designers/DMs can modify this as well)

Mechanics

Any opponent who receives a critical hit must make a fortitude save or die.
The DC is 10 + 1/2 attacker character level + strength modifier.
An opponent rolling a 1 will fail the fortitude save roll and die.

Landing critical hits

The attack roll firstly needs to land in the threat range.
The attack must hit. 
Concealment (ie 50% from improved invisibility) must be beaten. 
The attack roll has to either be a 20, or the attack roll plus the attack bonus plus modifiers (ie +2 AB from flanking) beating the opponents AC.
A threat roll will then occur. The threat roll plus AB plus modifiers must beat the opponents AC. Rolling a 20 with a threat roll will not lead to a critical hit, if the AC is not beaten.
The opponent must be susceptible to critical hits. Critical immune enemies (palemaster level 10 or higher, undead) will not receive a critical hit.

Countering devastating critical

Critical hit immunity from Palemaster (or items from your environment)
Critical hit immunity from extremely high AC
- important to note a character will lose all their dexterity AC (unless they have uncanny dodge), dodge AC and tumble AC if they are flatfooted, always make sure you are doing something in combat
High fortitude saves (will not prevent a '1' roll which is an automatic fail)
Epic dodge to remove the first attack, which is the most likely to critical hit

Ranged weaponry (if they are melee)
Bigby's hand spells, if you can beat their spell resistance
Death armor/Elemental Shield/Mestil's Acid Sheath/Wounding Whispers then Shapechange -> Iron Golem
Critical immune summons (elementals, undead) to tank
Lots of stacked traps

Let other party members deal with the problem

When to take devastating critical in strength builds

If you have adequate AB (base 40+ if possible)
If you have enough feats (6 feats is a large investment)

Is it overpowered?

Definitely

Are other things overpowered?

Definitely

(eg. in a non rest restricted environment, a wizard/cleric can simply cast haste or drink a potion of speed, cast Greater Sanctuary, then cast Wail of the banshee / Implosion then Greater Sanctuary in one round. Repeat until you run out of spells, then rest again. Unlimited death dealing. )

Should it be nerfed?

Probably not, give those beefcakes some fun.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
The main problem with enabling Dev Crit is that the entire server/environment needs to be balanced around it.

For PvM, any major mobs will need either high fortitude saves (making DC casters less effective) or immunity to critical hits (which affects most non-casters). Higher AC isn't an effective counter for PvM since raising mob AC will negatively affect most non-casters. Even if mob saves are high enough to resist Dev Crit, unless the server has changed 1's to not cause auto-fails then eventually a Dev Crit will trigger and kill anything that isn't immune to critical hits. This means that for big bosses to actually be threatening the only choices are to remove auto-fails, make them all immune to critical hits, or edit/remove Dev Crit.

Most PvP environments nerf Dev Crit but they usually nerf other OP feats and spells too. Altering or removing Dev Crit, Epic Warding, Greater Sanctuary, Harm/Heal, HiPS, IGMS, Time Stop, and True Seeing are usually among the first changes PvP servers make due to how unbalanced they are in vanilla NWN.

A human Figh14/WM25/Bard1 dual-wielding kukris is a fairly simple build that shows how powerful Dev Crit can be. In addition to high AB, high damage, and UMD, with +12 STR it also has a 48 DC Dev Crit and a 13-20 threat range (10-20 with keened kukris). A maxed Implosion can be cast twice a round and has a 48 DC, the main difference being Spellcraft boosts saves against Implosion so Dev Crit is harder to resist.

Here is a list of the average number of critical hits per round from the build for the important AC range.

The key is "Ha_Ke" = hasted + keened kukris, "Ha_NK" = hasted + non-keened kukris, "NH_Ke" = non-hasted + keened kukris, "NH_NK" = non-hasted + non-keened kukris.
This assumes +12 STR but only +0 weapons, if +X weapons are available in your environment then add X to the AC (eg. with +5 kukris the AC range is 46-85). Concealment and Epic Dodge aren't factored into this calculation, just AC.

When hasted and using keened kukris, against creatures with 42 AC or less the build does an average of 3.85 critical hits per round. This decreases to 2.0725 against creatures with 61 AC, which is slightly better than the 2 per round from Implosion. This also shows why increasing AC isn't a viable tactic to deal with Dev Crit in PvM. In order to reduce the average number of critical hits per round to less than 1 a creature needs an AC of 67 (72 in a +5 EB environment), which seriously restricts the number of viable PvM builds.

We really need a module designer or a DM to respond here :) 

Here are some extra ideas to counter the Dev Crit warrior you have made:

-> give the monster ITWF dev crit dual kukri as well with a fortitude score of 70
-> give the monster improved disarm, so those kukris are never in your hand
-> make the monster a huge rust monster so the kukris become rusted remains
-> give the monster so much AC that you will never crit

Or just make the boss a permahasted mage with True Sight: 
- Time Stop / Mord / Time Stop / Bigby 9 then IGMS until the fighter is dead, bye bye fighter

Pretty sure I've encountered module AI's smart enough to cast bigby's on me regularly. 

Bigbys is a nightmare. 

Successful Bigby's on a solo fighter = usually equals dead fighter.

Although I understand a possible counter to this is to carry a few Mord's scrolls around to self-Mord yourself... only to get Bigby'ed again I guess...

Or be a monk with extreme spell resistance as @webshaman1 and others have been investigating


On the topic of mages hehe, this is a reddit post you might find interesting:





Anyway I'm not going to pretend its overpowered, it is absolutely overpowered for sure!

Just other stuff is overpowered too. 

And I'm cool with that :)

We have all these on WoG, btw (not so sure about the Fort of 70 ;) ), and the Devver has no kukris.

We do not have Rustzilla yet, despite my best efforts.  But we do have...improved Rusty 2.0.  In hordes.

The main problem with Dev Crit is it threatens insta-bork on a 1.  Fail the save, and bam!  And since it can be threatened indefinitely (no charges, no spell slot limitations, etc), eventually that 1 is gonna roll.

Make the AC too high, and no one is hitting the Boss, except with 20s.  Perhaps a dexxer, but no-one else.

Making immunity to crits available to everyone, and bleh.  Giving immunity to crits to every boss, m0b, and his uncle is also meh.  Congrats, you just made Rogues & Co. very unhappy.

Improved Disarm makes players howl "Mah favorite [insert whatever it is that is so important] is GONE!!!  WTF!!!"

Rusties are worse.  Rustzilla would make peeps avoid the area worse than they do The Ghost Tower of Inverness and the Deck of Hazards!

Dev Crit is very difficult to balance, and it is primarily one of the reasons it gets tossed.

For me personally, I prefer environments where it is active - provided that the builders have not gone totally insane with trying to "proof" everything against it.

posts.author: Zanithar
posts.content:
People choose what and how they approach balancing things. DevCrit is one of those things that needs to be modified for PvP balance along with a broader list found above. PVE is a different thing and balancing it is a little more flexible.

It is, very much, one of those key decisions that sets the tone (box) of a server. As such it is an easy choice to drop letting other things set that tone. WoG is the first server I have played on where it was not removed or modified. Like most things ... some pros and some cons ... I like different boxes to play in though, it makes me try different things and refreshes my interest.

It also makes me appreciate some of the builds touted as “best of breed” that have previously left me thinking WTF ...
